oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John and Calvin and Barlow Roberts
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Free Hill Community Center
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community; Performing Identity
Musicians; Schools
African American musicians; African American men
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African American three-piece string band, two older men with fiddles, a younger man in center with banjo, seated outside in straight back wooden chairs against an unpainted frame structure.

Free Hill, a neighborhood containing homes, a church and cemetery, and a former Rosenwald School, located on a hill near Celina, Tennessee, is a historically African American-owned community. There is an intact legacy of old-time string band musicians as well as sacred music associated with Free Hill. The Tennessee Folklore Society, in conjunction with the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project at the Department of Conservation, recorded an album entitled "Free Hill: A Sound Portrait of a Rural Afro-American Community (TFS 107) in 1983. It included not only musical selections but also historical remembrances and local lore. This photograph of members of the Barlow family is on display in the Free Hill Community Center, a well-preserved example of a two-room Rosenwald School.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Center for Historic Preservation, Middle Tennessee State University
